entries.title: Adult CPR Protocol
entries.text:
Comprehensive Adult CPR Protocol:
1. Scene Safety Assessment
   - Check for environmental hazards
   - Use personal protective equipment
   - Ensure electrical safety if defibrillation may be needed

2. Check Responsiveness
   - Tap shoulders firmly
   - Loudly ask "Are you okay?"
   - Note any response or movement

3. Activate Emergency Response
   - Call emergency services (911)
   - Send someone for AED
   - If alone, call before starting CPR

4. Check Breathing and Pulse
   - Look for chest rise/fall
   - Check carotid pulse for 10 seconds
   - Note abnormal breathing patterns

5. Begin Chest Compressions
   - Center of chest on breastbone
   - Depth: 2-2.4 inches
   - Rate: 100-120 per minute
   - Allow full chest recoil
   - Minimize interruptions

6. Airway Management
   - Head-tilt chin-lift
   - Check for visible obstructions
   - Remove loose dentures

7. Rescue Breaths
   - 2 breaths after 30 compressions
   - Each breath 1 second duration
   - Watch for chest rise
   - Resume compressions immediately

8. Continue CPR Cycles
   - Maintain 30:2 ratio
   - Switch providers every 2 minutes
   - Minimize interruptions

9. AED Integration
   - Power on AED
   - Follow voice prompts
   - Clear victim during analysis
   - Resume CPR immediately after shock

10. Special Considerations
    - Pregnancy: Left lateral tilt
    - Trauma: Stabilize spine
    - Drowning: Begin with rescue breaths

entries.title: Pediatric Emergency Care
entries.text:
Pediatric Emergency Assessment and Treatment:
1. Primary Assessment (ABCDE)
   A. Airway
      - Check patency
      - Look for foreign bodies
      - Position appropriately
   
   B. Breathing
      - Count respiratory rate
      - Observe work of breathing
      - Listen for abnormal sounds
   
   C. Circulation
      - Check pulse strength
      - Assess capillary refill
      - Look for bleeding
   
   D. Disability
      - Check consciousness (AVPU)
      - Assess pupils
      - Check blood glucose
   
   E. Exposure
      - Check temperature
      - Look for rashes/injuries
      - Maintain dignity

2. Age-Specific Vital Signs
   Infants (0-12 months):
   - Heart rate: 100-160
   - Resp rate: 30-60
   - BP systolic: 65-90

   Toddlers (1-3 years):
   - Heart rate: 90-150
   - Resp rate: 24-40
   - BP systolic: 80-100

   School Age (4-12):
   - Heart rate: 70-120
   - Resp rate: 18-30
   - BP systolic: 90-110

3. Emergency Interventions
   - Airway positioning
   - Oxygen therapy
   - IV/IO access
   - Fluid resuscitation
   - Temperature management

entries.title: Advanced Wound Assessment
entries.text:
Comprehensive Wound Assessment Protocol:
1. Initial Evaluation
   - Mechanism of injury
   - Time since injury
   - Contamination risk
   - Associated injuries

2. Wound Classification
   Clean:
   - Surgical, non-traumatic
   - Minimal contamination
   - Primary closure possible

   Clean-Contaminated:
   - Controlled opening of viscera
   - Minor breaks in technique

   Contaminated:
   - Open traumatic wounds
   - Gross spillage from GI tract
   - Non-purulent inflammation

   Dirty:
   - Active infection present
   - Visceral perforation
   - Delayed treatment

3. Depth Assessment
   - Superficial (epidermis)
   - Partial thickness (dermis)
   - Full thickness (subcutaneous)
   - Deep tissue involvement

4. Vascular Assessment
   - Capillary refill
   - Pulse check distal to wound
   - Temperature of affected area
   - Color assessment

5. Neurological Check
   - Sensory function
   - Motor function
   - Pain assessment
   - Paresthesia

6. Risk Factors
   - Diabetes
   - Immunosuppression
   - Peripheral vascular disease
   - Malnutrition
   - Age extremes

7. Documentation
   - Size and location
   - Wound bed characteristics
   - Exudate type/amount
   - Surrounding skin condition
   - Photography if appropriate

entries.title: Asthma Exacerbation Management
entries.text:
Comprehensive Asthma Management Protocol:
1. Severity Assessment
   Mild:
   - Speaking in sentences
   - RR slightly elevated
   - No accessory muscle use
   - O2 sat > 95%

   Moderate:
   - Speaking in phrases
   - RR 20-30
   - Accessory muscle use
   - O2 sat 90-95%

   Severe:
   - Speaking in words
   - RR > 30
   - Marked accessory muscle use
   - O2 sat < 90%

2. Initial Management
   - Positioning (sitting upright)
   - Oxygen therapy if needed
   - Initial SABA treatment
   - Vital signs monitoring

3. Medication Administration
   First Line:
   - SABA (albuterol) 4-8 puffs q20min
   - Consider ipratropium bromide
   - Systemic corticosteroids

   Second Line:
   - Magnesium sulfate
   - Continuous nebulization
   - IV beta-agonists

4. Monitoring
   - Peak flow measurements
   - Pulse oximetry
   - Work of breathing
   - Mental status
   - Response to treatment

5. Discharge Criteria
   - Minimal respiratory distress
   - O2 sat > 90% on room air
   - PEFR > 70% predicted
   - Adequate social support

entries.title: Toxic Exposure Management
entries.text:
Comprehensive Toxicology Management:
1. Initial Assessment
   - Airway protection
   - Breathing adequacy
   - Circulation status
   - Mental status
   - Temperature

2. History Collection
   - Substance(s) involved
   - Route of exposure
   - Time since exposure
   - Amount/concentration
   - Intentionality
   - Available containers

3. Common Toxidromes
   Anticholinergic:
   - Hyperthermia
   - Mydriasis
   - Dry mucous membranes
   - Urinary retention
   - Delirium

   Cholinergic:
   - Bradycardia
   - Bronchorrhea
   - Salivation
   - Lacrimation
   - Diaphoresis

   Opioid:
   - Miosis
   - Respiratory depression
   - CNS depression
   - Bradycardia
   - Hypothermia

4. Decontamination
   Dermal:
   - Remove clothing
   - Copious irrigation
   - Special considerations

   Gastrointestinal:
   - Activated charcoal
   - Whole bowel irrigation
   - Gastric lavage

5. Antidote Administration
   - Naloxone for opioids
   - N-acetylcysteine for acetaminophen
   - Flumazenil for benzodiazepines
   - Glucagon for beta-blockers
   - Calcium for calcium channel blockers

6. Monitoring
   - Vital signs
   - Mental status
   - Organ function
   - ECG monitoring
   - Blood levels

entries.title: Using an AED
entries.text:
AED (Automated External Defibrillator) Usage Steps:
1. Power on the AED
2. Expose patient's chest, ensure it's dry
3. Attach pads correctly:
   - Right pad under right collarbone
   - Left pad on left side under armpit
4. Let AED analyze heart rhythm
5. Clear the patient during analysis
6. If shock advised:
   - Ensure nobody is touching patient
   - Press shock button
7. Resume CPR immediately after shock
Special considerations: Remove metal jewelry, medication patches. Don't use on wet surfaces or if patient is lying on metal.

entries.title: Severe Bleeding Control
entries.text:
Managing Severe Bleeding:
1. Apply direct pressure with clean cloth or gauze
2. Maintain firm, continuous pressure for at least 15 minutes
3. Add more gauze if needed without removing original dressing
4. Elevate injured area if possible
5. Apply tourniquet if bleeding can't be controlled and is on a limb:
   - Place 2-3 inches above wound
   - Tighten until bleeding stops
   - Note time of application
For internal bleeding signs (bruising, blood in vomit/stool, cold/clammy skin), seek immediate medical attention.

entries.title: Heat and Cold Emergencies
entries.text:
Managing Temperature-Related Emergencies:
Heat Exhaustion:
1. Move to cool place
2. Remove excess clothing
3. Apply cool, wet cloths
4. Sip water slowly
5. Seek medical care if symptoms worsen

Heat Stroke (Medical Emergency):
1. Call emergency services
2. Move to cool area
3. Remove outer clothing
4. Apply cool packs to neck, armpits, groin
5. Monitor breathing and consciousness

Hypothermia:
1. Move to warm area
2. Remove wet clothing
3. Warm core body gradually
4. Use warm blankets
5. Give warm drinks if conscious
6. Seek medical attention

Frostbite:
1. Move to warm area
2. Don't rub affected area
3. Immerse in warm (not hot) water
4. Don't use direct heat
5. Protect from refreezing
6. Seek medical attention

entries.title: Mass Casualty Triage
entries.text:
START Triage Protocol:
1. Initial Scene Assessment
   - Scene safety evaluation
   - Resource assessment
   - Establish command structure
   - Set up triage zones

2. Primary Triage
   Walking wounded (Green):
   - Can walk
   - Follow commands
   - Minor injuries

   Immediate (Red):
   - Respiratory rate >30 or <10
   - Perfusion: Cap refill >2 sec
   - Mental status: Unable to follow commands

   Delayed (Yellow):
   - Non-ambulatory
   - Serious injuries but not immediate
   - Stable vital signs

   Deceased/Expectant (Black):
   - No breathing after airway opened
   - Obviously deceased
   - Injuries incompatible with life

3. Secondary Triage
   - Detailed assessment
   - Documentation
   - Treatment priorities
   - Transport decisions

4. Resource Management
   - Personnel allocation
   - Equipment distribution
   - Transport coordination
   - Communication channels

entries.title: Critical Antidote Administration
entries.text:
Emergency Antidote Protocol:
1. Opioid Overdose
   Naloxone Administration:
   - Initial dose: 0.4-2mg IV/IM/IN
   - Repeat q2-3min if needed
   - Maximum 10mg
   - Monitor for withdrawal

2. Beta Blocker Toxicity
   Glucagon Protocol:
   - Bolus: 5-10mg IV
   - Infusion: 2-5mg/hour
   - Monitor glucose levels
   - Watch for vomiting

3. Calcium Channel Blocker
   Calcium Protocol:
   - Calcium chloride 1g IV
   - Calcium gluconate 3g IV
   - High-dose insulin therapy
   - Vasopressor support

4. Organophosphate Poisoning
   Atropine/Pralidoxime:
   - Atropine: 2-4mg IV q5-10min
   - Pralidoxime: 1-2g IV
   - Monitor secretions
   - Decontamination

5. Methanol/Ethylene Glycol
   Fomepizole Protocol:
   - Loading: 15mg/kg IV
   - Maintenance: 10mg/kg q12h
   - Adjust for hemodialysis
   - Monitor anion gap

entries.title: Needle Decompression
entries.text:
Tension Pneumothorax Decompression:
1. Indication Assessment
   - Respiratory distress
   - Absent breath sounds
   - Tracheal deviation
   - Hypotension
   - JVD

2. Site Selection
   Primary:
   - 2nd/3rd intercostal space
   - Midclavicular line
   - Above rib

   Alternative:
   - 4th/5th intercostal space
   - Anterior axillary line

3. Procedure Steps
   - Identify landmarks
   - Sterile preparation
   - Local anesthesia if time
   - Insert 14G catheter
   - Listen for rush of air
   - Secure catheter

4. Post-procedure
   - Chest tube preparation
   - Vital sign monitoring
   - CXR when possible
   - Documentation

entries.title: Surgical Cricothyroidotomy
entries.text:
Emergency Surgical Airway:
1. Indications
   - Failed intubation
   - Cannot ventilate
   - Cannot oxygenate
   - Upper airway obstruction

2. Anatomy Identification
   - Thyroid cartilage
   - Cricoid cartilage
   - Cricothyroid membrane
   - Midline vessels

3. Equipment Needed
   - Scalpel (#10 blade)
   - Bougie
   - 6.0 ETT
   - Trach hook
   - Antiseptic

4. Procedure Steps
   - Identify landmarks
   - Stabilize larynx
   - Vertical skin incision
   - Horizontal membrane cut
   - Insert bougie
   - Railroad ETT
   - Confirm placement

5. Complications
   - Bleeding
   - False passage
   - Posterior wall injury
   - Subcutaneous emphysema

entries.title: Acute Burn Management
entries.text:
Initial Burn Care Protocol:
1. Primary Survey
   - Airway assessment
   - Breathing evaluation
   - Circulation status
   - Associated trauma

2. Burn Assessment
   Rule of Nines:
   - Head/Neck: 9%
   - Each arm: 9%
   - Chest (front): 18%
   - Back: 18%
   - Each leg: 18%
   - Groin: 1%

3. Fluid Resuscitation
   Parkland Formula:
   - 4mL × kg × %TBSA
   - First 24 hours
   - Half in first 8 hours
   - Monitor urine output

4. Wound Care
   - Stop burning process
   - Remove jewelry
   - Clean wounds
   - Apply dressings
   - Tetanus status

5. Special Considerations
   - Chemical burns
   - Electrical burns
   - Circumferential burns
   - Inhalation injury
   - Hypothermia risk

entries.title: Pediatric Septic Shock
entries.text:
Pediatric Sepsis Protocol:
1. Recognition
   Early Signs:
   - Tachycardia
   - Fever/Hypothermia
   - Altered mental status
   - Poor perfusion
   
   Late Signs:
   - Hypotension
   - Weak pulses
   - Mottled skin
   - Decreased urine output

2. Initial Resuscitation
   First Hour:
   - IV/IO access
   - Labs/Cultures
   - Antibiotics
   - Fluid boluses

3. Fluid Therapy
   - 20mL/kg boluses
   - Reassess after each
   - Up to 60mL/kg
   - Watch for overload

4. Vasoactive Support
   First Line:
   - Epinephrine
   - Norepinephrine
   
   Second Line:
   - Dopamine
   - Vasopressin

5. Antimicrobial Therapy
   - Broad spectrum
   - Source control
   - Adjust for resistance
   - Monitor response

entries.title: Electrical Storm Management
entries.text:
Managing Recurrent VT/VF:
1. Initial Stabilization
   - Defibrillation prn
   - Airway management
   - IV access
   - Monitor setup

2. Medication Protocol
   First Line:
   - Amiodarone 150mg IV
   - Beta blocker
   - Sedation

   Second Line:
   - Lidocaine
   - Procainamide
   - Magnesium

3. Reversible Causes
   - Ischemia
   - Electrolytes
   - pH disturbance
   - Drug toxicity
   - Device malfunction

4. Advanced Interventions
   - Overdrive pacing
   - Stellate block
   - ECMO consideration
   - Ablation planning

5. Prevention Strategy
   - Optimize medications
   - Device programming
   - Risk factor control
   - Follow-up plan

entries.title: Severe Malaria Management
entries.text:
Severe Malaria Protocol:
1. Diagnostic Criteria
   Clinical:
   - Impaired consciousness
   - Severe anemia
   - Acute kidney injury
   - ARDS
   - Shock

   Laboratory:
   - Parasitemia >10%
   - Lactate >5
   - pH <7.2
   - Glucose <40

2. Initial Treatment
   Antimalarial Therapy:
   - IV Artesunate preferred
   - Quinine if unavailable
   - Loading dose calculation
   - Maintenance schedule

3. Supportive Care
   - Fluid management
   - Glucose control
   - Seizure prophylaxis
   - Blood products
   - Ventilation support

4. Monitoring
   - Parasitemia q12h
   - Vital signs q1h
   - Mental status
   - Urine output
   - Complications

5. Exchange Transfusion
   Indications:
   - Parasitemia >30%
   - Severe symptoms
   - End organ damage

entries.title: Status Epilepticus Management
entries.text:
Status Epilepticus Treatment Protocol:
1. Initial Phase (0-5 min)
   - Airway protection
   - Oxygen supplementation
   - Vital signs monitoring
   - Establish IV access

2. First-Line Treatment (5-20 min)
   Benzodiazepines:
   - Lorazepam 0.1mg/kg IV
   - Midazolam 10mg IM
   - Diazepam 0.15mg/kg IV

3. Second-Line Treatment (20-40 min)
   Choose one:
   - Fosphenytoin 20mg PE/kg
   - Valproate 40mg/kg
   - Levetiracetam 60mg/kg
   - Phenobarbital 15mg/kg

4. Third-Line Treatment (40-60 min)
   - General anesthesia
   - Continuous EEG monitoring
   - ICU admission
   - Intubation preparation

5. Ongoing Management
   - Continuous vital monitoring
   - Electrolyte correction
   - Temperature management
   - Neurological checks

entries.title: Thyroid Storm Management
entries.text:
Thyroid Storm Protocol:
1. Diagnosis (Burch-Wartofsky Score)
   - Temperature (35-41°C)
   - CNS effects
   - GI-hepatic dysfunction
   - Cardiovascular dysfunction
   - Precipitant history

2. Initial Stabilization
   - Cooling measures
   - IV fluid resuscitation
   - Electrolyte correction
   - ICU admission

3. Medication Protocol
   First Hour:
   - PTU 500-1000mg load
   - Hydrocortisone 100mg IV
   - Propranolol 60-80mg
   
   Subsequent:
   - Lugol's solution
   - Cholestyramine
   - Continued PTU

4. Supportive Care
   - Cardiac monitoring
   - Temperature control
   - Fluid balance
   - Nutrition support

entries.title: Massive Hemoptysis
entries.text:
Massive Hemoptysis Management:
1. Initial Assessment
   - Airway protection
   - Bleeding quantification
   - Vital signs
   - Oxygenation status

2. Position Patient
   - Bleeding side down
   - Head of bed up
   - Ready for intubation

3. Airway Management
   - Large bore ETT
   - Double lumen consideration
   - Bronchial blockers
   - Suction preparation

4. Medical Management
   - Tranexamic acid
   - Blood products
   - Antibiotics if indicated
   - Correction of coagulopathy

5. Definitive Care
   - Bronchial arteriography
   - Embolization
   - Surgical consultation
   - ICU monitoring

entries.title: Perimortem Cesarean Section
entries.text:
Emergency Cesarean Protocol:
1. Indications
   - Maternal cardiac arrest
   - Gestational age >20 weeks
   - No ROSC within 4 minutes
   - Uterus above umbilicus

2. Team Activation
   - Code team leader
   - Obstetric surgeon
   - Neonatology
   - Blood bank
   - Operating room

3. Procedure Timing
   - Decision within 4 minutes
   - Delivery within 5 minutes
   - Continue CPR throughout
   - Minimal preparation

4. Equipment Needed
   - Scalpel
   - Retractors
   - Cord clamps
   - Suction
   - Neonatal resuscitation

5. Post-Procedure
   - Maternal resuscitation
   - Uterine closure
   - Neonatal care
   - Documentation
   - Family support

entries.title: Cyanide Poisoning
entries.text:
Cyanide Toxicity Protocol:
1. Recognition
   Early Signs:
   - Bitter almond odor
   - Anxiety/confusion
   - Tachypnea
   - Vomiting

   Late Signs:
   - Seizures
   - Cardiovascular collapse
   - Lactic acidosis
   - Coma

2. Initial Actions
   - Remove from exposure
   - PPE for rescuers
   - 100% oxygen
   - IV access

3. Antidote Administration
   Hydroxocobalamin:
   - 5g IV over 15 minutes
   - May repeat once
   - Monitor response

   Alternative:
   - Sodium thiosulfate
   - Sodium nitrite
   - Amyl nitrite

4. Supportive Care
   - Airway management
   - Hemodynamic support
   - Seizure control
   - Temperature regulation

entries.title: Severe Hyponatremia Correction
entries.text:
Hyponatremia Management Protocol:
1. Assessment
   Symptoms:
   - Mental status changes
   - Seizures
   - Respiratory distress
   - Focal deficits

2. Initial Management
   Severe Symptoms:
   - 3% saline 100mL bolus
   - Repeat if needed
   - Target 4-6 mEq/L rise
   - Maximum 8 mEq/L/24h

3. Ongoing Correction
   - Regular sodium checks
   - Fluid restriction
   - Underlying cause treatment
   - Osmotic demyelination prevention

4. Special Situations
   - Exercise-associated
   - Drug-induced
   - Endocrine disorders
   - Heart failure

entries.title: Crush Syndrome Management
entries.text:
Crush Injury Protocol:
1. Scene Assessment
   - Entrapment duration
   - Affected body parts
   - Associated injuries
   - Extrication planning

2. Pre-Release Care
   - IV access
   - Fluid loading
   - Pain control
   - Monitoring

3. Release Phase
   - Tourniquet readiness
   - Fluid continuation
   - Hyperkalemia monitoring
   - Acidosis correction

4. Post-Release Care
   - Compartment monitoring
   - Renal protection
   - Wound care
   - Fasciotomy assessment

entries.title: Mechanical Circulatory Support
entries.text:
ECMO Initiation Protocol:
1. Indication Assessment
   - Refractory shock
   - Cardiac arrest
   - Respiratory failure
   - Bridge to intervention

2. Pre-Implementation
   - Team activation
   - Equipment check
   - Consent process
   - Imaging review

3. Cannulation Process
   - Site selection
   - Ultrasound guidance
   - Heparin administration
   - Position confirmation

4. Initial Settings
   - Flow rates
   - Oxygen delivery
   - Anticoagulation
   - Ventilator adjustment

entries.title: Acute Agitation Management
entries.text:
Agitated Patient Protocol:
1. Risk Assessment
   - Environment safety
   - Weapon screening
   - Exit route planning
   - Staff positioning

2. De-escalation
   - Verbal techniques
   - Space management
   - Limit stimulation
   - Clear communication

3. Chemical Restraint
   First Line:
   - Haloperidol 5mg
   - Lorazepam 2mg
   - Combination therapy

4. Physical Restraint
   - Team coordination
   - Safe positioning
   - Vital monitoring
   - Documentation

entries.title: Variceal Hemorrhage
entries.text:
Variceal Bleeding Protocol:
1. Initial Stabilization
   - Large bore IV access
   - Blood products
   - Antibiotics
   - Airway assessment

2. Medical Management
   - Octreotide drip
   - PPI therapy
   - Ceftriaxone
   - Vitamin K

3. Endoscopic Planning
   - Timing (<12 hours)
   - Band ligation
   - Sclerotherapy
   - TIPS consideration

4. Post-procedure Care
   - Monitoring
   - Rebleeding prevention
   - Portal pressure
   - Follow-up plan

entries.title: TTP Crisis Management
entries.text:
Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura Protocol:
1. Diagnostic Criteria
   - Thrombocytopenia
   - MAHA
   - Neurological symptoms
   - Renal dysfunction
   - Fever

2. Initial Treatment
   - Plasma exchange
   - Methylprednisolone
   - Rituximab consideration
   - Caplacizumab

3. Monitoring
   - Platelet count
   - LDH levels
   - Mental status
   - Organ function

4. Complications
   - Bleeding
   - Thrombosis
   - Line infections
   - Treatment failure
